awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track A: Leveraging Existing Fiber-Optic Cables to Identify and Manage Urban Environmental Hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
Cities around the world are dealing with the compounding challenges of aging infrastructure and climate change. This manifests as issues such as leaky sewer pipes, chronic flooding, and geotechnical failures. Many of these issues are related to the subsurface environment that plays many critical roles for cities, but for which there is a lack of real-time information. Moreover, communities that are socio-economically disadvantaged and/or composed primarily of racial minorities are commonly more exposed to more environmental hazards than those in the majority population or neighborhoods with higher incomes. Cities are in need of cost-effective and equitable ways to identify, monitor and prioritize interventions to manage these issues. This research leverages existing telecommunication fiber-optic infrastructure that is nearly ubiquitous in all cities. The approach involves a novel, optic fiber, subsurface, environmental sensor network. The project targets locations that have fiber option cables and that are subjected to certain types of infrastructure issues and hazards such as subsidence or land failure, leaking sewer pipes, or poor drainage. Data will be collected from select locations that leverage existing cables and sensors (e.g., sewer flow sensors) or other data on environmental hazards (e.g., sinkholes, flooding reports, or inventory data for landslide proneness), information that comes from city partners. These external sensors are used to validate the fiber optic sensing against traditional sensing approaches and/or environmental hazard data. This project allows demonstration and testing of new real-time, high spatial resolution, easy-to-implement, low cost, sensing system that has potential to revolutionize how installed city infrastructure is managed to address civic challenges and create smart, sustainable cities. Because of its setting, aging infrastructure, and involvement of researchers with municipal groups, Pittsburgh PA was selected for the initial implementation. Broader impacts include development of a new type of urban infrastructure and ground hazard monitoring and warning system, improved city services, and new insights and lessons learned that can facilitate broader implementation of this potentially impactful, yet low-cost tool for urban environments.

This research planning phase will establish scientific foundations that enable the civic partners to expand the implementation of the fiber optic cable, geophysical, sensing technology citywide to identify and monitor environmental and infrastructure hazards. The effort will deploy the newly developed intervention to inform city and urban decision makers to help them manage infrastructures hazards in a more cost-effective, timely, and equitable manner. If successful, this project will improve early warning capability for multiple hazards in urban areas, help manage and minimize these hazards in cost-effective and equitable manners, impact the design of future infrastructure networks and more resilient cities, develop workforce for implementation of the technology, and highlight potential opportunities for urban planners to increase environmental equity in the siting of telecom optical fibers. This project is transformative because the technical and practice outcome based on telecom dark fiber we demonstrate in this project could be used for other smart cities.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track A. Living in a changing climate: pre-disaster action around adaptation, resilience, and mitigation—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In stage 1, we worked with our civic partners to understand key hazards in the Pittsburgh region, existing monitoring and availability of relevant data, and challenges managing geophysical hazards in the region. Understanding these issues was necessary to understand how to pilot new methods of monitoring water infrastructure and geo-environmental hazards using existing fiber-optic cables. The civic partners included sewer system managers, landslide experts, city planners, and fiber-optic/telecommunications companies in Pittsburgh. We had monthly virtual meetings with team members and civic partners as well as several individual meetings with partners for specific needs. The main results from stage 1 include:

1)  identifying relevant issues and hazards in the community to help inform focal sites

In our earliest meetings with civic partners, we discussed which geo-environmental hazards were of greatest concern and impact in the City of Pittsburgh. This included understanding areas most prevalent to landslides, sinkholes, flooding, and sewer infrastructure leaks. We discussed current approaches to monitoring or mapping these hazards, as well as the communities impacted by these hazards. We identified three target communities that best intersect the fiber-optic network, PWSA flow monitoring locations, and landslide prone slopes.

2) discussing the availability of existing data to compare with fiber-optic signals

In order to validate fiber-optic-derived signals for monitoring geophysical hazards, it is essential to have other types of data with which we can compare. One of these types of data is sewer flow rates. These data can be used to derive information on several characteristics such as sewer inflow and infiltration. In our meetings, PWSA shared information and insights on their current and past flow monitoring locations and the extensive cost of these monitoring efforts. As such, flow monitoring is typically only in place for very limited periods of time in selected locations. We have overlaid these monitoring locations with fiber-optic cable locations to evaluate co-location. Because of the limited number of current monitoring locations, we likely will need to re-install a flow sensor at a past monitoring location, in order to obtain data in the direct vicinity to a fiber-optic table. Additional City of Pittsburgh collaborators helped us understand areas vulnerable to landslides and sinkholes. There are no existing sensors deployed to monitor these features, and thus any fiber-optic data collection would be proposed in the areas known to be generally vulnerable to these hazards.  

3) connecting with two major telecommunication companies - Five telecom companies were evaluated and two were identified as having the appropriate, local fiber-optic networks. DQE Communications and Windstream were included in planning meetings regarding access to their fiber-optic cables in Pittsburgh. The partner from DQE Communications provided the map of their existing fiber-optic network and a delineation of in-conduit and aerial cables. After discussions and evaluations of fiber extent, we decided to pursue a partnership with DQE, given that their dark fiber is co-located with communities who are experiencing hazards of interest as well as who are vulnerable to these hazards.

4) initiate non-disclosure agreements (NDA)- these NDAs are between Penn State and PWSA and DQE to allow access to critical data. The NDA process was started in Dec 2022 and is expected to be completed by June 2023. This will ensure access to necessary data at the initiation of Stage 2, so that we can initiate the fiber-optic interrogation with accurate locations and validation using other monitoring data.

5) hone project plans, timeline, and outcomes for the full Stage 2 proposal - With all information from above, we plan to test and validate the DAS technology with two potential dark fiber routes provided by DQE (see below Figure 4). Route 1 begins at a DQE hub, through three North Side neighborhoods, past the Community College of Allegheny County, to the North Shore and adjacent to two professional sport stadiums. This overall zone offers excellent fiber-optic flow monitoring and an interesting cross-section of land uses spanning residential, commercial, and industrial. As mentioned, the South Shore lacks a community, but does sit at the foothills of Mount Washington — a community immediately impacted by the stability of these slopes. Route 2 runs along the Hill District, Uptown, South Oakland, and Oakcliffe communities. This provides additional opportunities for calibration against flow monitors, but also provides an opportunity to engage with three marginalized areas that have been impacted by urban renewal and large, federally-funded projects that have historically separated them from two major central business districts — Downtown and Central Oakland. Both routes are about 5 miles long.
